options: An obligation that contradicts another obligation
An obligation that applies when you've violated a primary duty
An obligation that is impossible to fulfill
An obligation that you can choose to ignore
hint: If you fail your primary duty, what should you do then?
explanation: Contrary-to-duty (CTD) obligations specify what you ought to do when you've already violated a primary duty. Example: You ought not steal. But IF you steal, you ought to return what you stole. CTD obligations pose challenges for deontic logic's formalization.
visual_concept: Primary: Don't break promises. CTD: If you break a promise, apologize. Second-level duties for when first-level fails.
